hotspots.label: Reflective Glass Windows
hotspots.fact: These glass windows reflect light from the sun and other buildings, which is a physical property of the glass material. When light bounces off a shiny surface like glass, it travels in a new direction—this is called reflection. This is why you can see the old building reflected in the modern glass building's windows!

vocabulary.definition: When light bounces off a shiny surface and travels in a new direction, like when you see yourself in a mirror.

hotspots.label: Transparent and Opaque Materials
hotspots.fact: The glass on the right side is transparent, which means light passes through it so you can see inside the building. The tan-colored stone walls are opaque, which means light cannot pass through them. Different materials have different physical properties that affect how light interacts with them!

vocabulary.definition: A material that lets light pass through it so you can see clearly through it, like clean glass or water.

hotspots.label: Building Structure and Strength
hotspots.fact: This tall building is held up by forces working together—gravity pulls the building down, and the metal and stone framework pushes up to support it. The strong materials and careful design of the building help it stay standing even when forces like wind push on it from different directions.

vocabulary.definition: A push or pull that can make something move, stop, or change direction, like gravity pulling things downward.

hotspots.label: Light and Shadow Patterns
hotspots.fact: You can see shadows created by the metal frames and building structures when sunlight hits them. Shadows form when opaque objects block light from passing through, creating dark areas behind them. The patterns and angles of these shadows change throughout the day as the sun moves across the sky!

vocabulary.definition: A dark area created when an object blocks light from shining through it or onto a surface.
